title: aims-PAX: Parallel Active eXploration for the automated construction of Machine Learning Force Fields
summary:
Recent advances in machine learning force fields (MLFF) have significantly
extended the capabilities of atomistic simulations. This progress highlights
the critical need for reliable reference datasets, accurate MLFFs, and,
crucially, efficient active learning strategies to enable robust modeling of
complex chemical and materials systems. Here, we introduce aims-PAX, an
automated, multi-trajectory active learning framework that streamlines the
development of MLFFs. Designed for both experts and newcomers, aims-PAX offers
a modular, high-performance workflow that couples flexible sampling with
scalable training across CPU and GPU architectures. Built on the widely adopted
ab initio code FHI-aims, the framework seamlessly integrates with
state-of-the-art ML models and supports pretraining using general-purpose (or
"foundational") models for rapid deployment in diverse systems. We demonstrate
the capabilities of aims-PAX on two challenging systems: a highly flexible
peptide and bulk CsPbI$_3$ perovskite. Across these cases, aims-PAX achieves a
reduction of up to two orders of magnitude in the number of required reference
calculations and enables over 20x speedup in AL cycle time through optimized
resource utilization. This positions aims-PAX as a powerful and versatile
platform for next-generation ML-driven atomistic simulations in both academic
and industrial settings.
tldr: The paper introduces aims-PAX, an automated active learning framework for constructing machine learning force fields (MLFFs), demonstrating significant reductions in reference calculations and AL cycle time on peptide and perovskite systems.
explanation: The paper presents aims-PAX, a new automated active learning framework designed to simplify the development of MLFFs. It's built on the ab initio code FHI-aims, integrates with modern ML models, and supports pretraining with general-purpose models. The framework offers efficient sampling and scalable training on CPUs and GPUs. The authors validate aims-PAX on simulations of a flexible peptide and bulk CsPbI3 perovskite, reporting a significant reduction in the number of necessary reference calculations and a considerable speedup in the active learning cycle. These results suggest a powerful tool for ML-driven atomistic simulations.
interests_alignment: The study shows the use of machine learning to accelerate atomistic simulation of peptides, specifically focusing on the creation of a force field. This directly aligns with my interests in machine learning for peptides and datasets of peptide structure, and the use of computation to study their structure.

title: Deep Learning Model for Amyloidogenicity Prediction using a Pre-trained Protein LLM
summary:
The prediction of amyloidogenicity in peptides and proteins remains a focal
point of ongoing bioinformatics. The crucial step in this field is to apply
advanced computational methodologies. Many recent approaches to predicting
amyloidogenicity within proteins are highly based on evolutionary motifs and
the individual properties of amino acids. It is becoming increasingly evident
that the sequence information-based features show high predictive performance.
Consequently, our study evaluated the contextual features of protein sequences
obtained from a pretrained protein large language model leveraging
bidirectional LSTM and GRU to predict amyloidogenic regions in peptide and
protein sequences. Our method achieved an accuracy of 84.5% on 10-fold
cross-validation and an accuracy of 83% in the test dataset. Our results
demonstrate competitive performance, highlighting the potential of LLMs in
enhancing the accuracy of amyloid prediction.
tldr: This paper presents a deep learning model leveraging a pre-trained protein LLM and bidirectional LSTM/GRU networks to predict amyloidogenic regions, achieving 84.5% accuracy in cross-validation and 83% in testing.
explanation: The paper explores the use of protein Large Language Models (LLMs) to enhance amyloidogenicity prediction. It uses contextual features extracted from an LLM and feeds them into bidirectional LSTM and GRU networks. The results show competitive performance compared to existing methods, suggesting that LLMs can improve the accuracy of amyloid prediction. The abstract highlights the method's accuracy on both cross-validation and test datasets, indicating a level of robustness.
interests_alignment: This paper aligns well with the research interests, specifically in machine learning for peptides and biomolecules, and peptide aggregation. The prediction of amyloidogenicity is directly related to peptide aggregation research. The use of LLMs is also a modern approach in the field of peptide ML that I'm interested in.
